eras.name: Tulip Mania (1636-1637)
eras.description: The Golden Age of Dutch trade. Bulbs are worth more than houses. Are you a speculative genius?

assets.name: Semper Augustus Bulb
assets.description: THE apex luxury asset. Cost: 12 acres of land. Highly speculative. If the mood turns, this crashes first.

assets.name: Viceroy Bulb
assets.description: Mid-tier nobility favorite. Traded for '2 lasts of wheat, 4 fat oxen'. High volatility expected.

assets.name: Admiral Van Der Eijck
assets.description: The 'People's Bulb'. Traded in taverns by drunk speculators. Extremely frothy volume.

assets.name: Gouda Cheese Co.
assets.description: Stability play. Dutch people eat cheese regardless of flower prices. Low growth, low risk.

assets.name: Dutch East India Co.
assets.description: Blue-chip empire. Monopolizes spice trade. A safe haven if the domestic market collapses.

assets.name: Amsterdam Real Estate
assets.description: Prime canal-side property. Solid value, but illiquid. Prices may dip if speculators sell homes to cover bulb debts.

assets.name: Ship Cargo Insurance
assets.description: High yield bonds. Pays out unless pirates or storms attack. Uncorrelated to flower mania.

assets.name: Wheat Futures
assets.description: Essential commodity. Prices are driven by harvest quality, not speculation. Hedge against chaos.

events.title: The Tavern Auctions
events.description: Frenzy in the taverns of Haarlem. A single Semper Augustus sells for the price of a mansion.

events.title: The Bubble Bursts
events.description: At an auction in Haarlem, no buyers appear. Panic spreads instantly across the Netherlands.

eras.name: The South Sea Bubble (1720)
eras.description: The first modern stock market crash. Even Isaac Newton lost a fortune. Can you outsmart the hype?

assets.name: South Sea Company
assets.description: The 'ETF' of the bubble. State-backed monopoly. Produces nothing but hype.

assets.name: Mississippi Company
assets.description: French equivalent. Rocketing on mythical Louisiana gold. Highly correlated to SSC.

assets.name: Royal Exchange
assets.description: Major insurer. Riding the mania's wave, but exposed to the crash.

assets.name: Bank of England
assets.description: The 'Old Lady'. Conservative lender. Hated by speculators, but durable.

assets.name: Hollow Sword Blade Co
assets.description: Shadow bank financing the bubble. Maximum risk, maximum leverage.

events.title: The Bubble Act
events.description: Parliament passes act to restrict new joint-stock companies, inadvertently popping the bubble.

events.title: Insiders Sell
events.description: SSC directors sell their shares. Panic ensues.

eras.name: The Great Crash (1929)
eras.description: The Roaring Twenties come to a screeching halt. The market loses 89% of its value.

assets.name: Radio Corp of America
assets.description: The 'Tech stock' of 1929. Radio is the future, but valuations are detached from reality.

assets.name: General Motors
assets.description: The engine of America. Solid production, but cyclical. Will suffer if consumers stop buying cars.

assets.name: U.S. Steel
assets.description: The backbone of infrastructure. Leader of the industrial economy. Highly sensitive to construction slowdowns.

assets.name: Dow Jones
assets.description: The market average. Short this to bet on the end of the Roaring Twenties.

assets.name: Government Bonds
assets.description: US Treasury Bonds. The ultimate safe haven. When stocks panic, money flees here.

assets.name: USD Cash
assets.description: King Cash. In a deflationary spiral, holding cash increases your purchasing power.

events.title: Market Peak
events.description: The Dow hits 381. Economists predict a 'permanently high plateau'.

events.title: Black Tuesday
events.description: 16 million shares traded. The market collapses.

eras.name: The Lost Decade (Japan 1989)
eras.description: Tokyo's Imperial Palace grounds are worth more than all of California. The Nikkei is unstoppable... right?

assets.name: Nikkei 225
assets.description: The symbol of Japan's economic miracle. Trading at 60x earnings. Is this sustainable?

assets.name: Sony Corp
assets.description: Global tech giant. The Walkman is everywhere. A solid business, but caught in the bubble valuation.

assets.name: Toyota Motor
assets.description: Efficient manufacturing perfection. Just-in-time production. A defensive play in an offensive market?

assets.name: Nippon Telegraph
assets.description: The most valuable company in history (1989). Privatized and puffed up by retail speculation.

assets.name: Tokyo Real Estate
assets.description: The Imperial Palace grounds > California? The epicenter of the bubble. Pure speculation.

assets.name: USD Currency
assets.description: The almighty Dollar. If the Yen collapses or the bubble pops, capital might flow back West.

assets.name: Gold
assets.description: Traditional store of value. Ignored during the tech/real estate boom, but shines in crisis.

events.title: Nikkei Hits All-Time High
events.description: The index peaks at 38,915. Champagne flows in Ginza.

events.title: The Crash Begins
events.description: The Bank of Japan sharply raises rates. The asset bubble pops violently.

eras.name: Asian Financial Crisis (1997)
eras.description: The 'Asian Tigers' are roaring, until the Thai Baht collapses. Contagion spreads across the Pacific.

assets.name: Thai Baht
assets.description: The trigger. Pegged to the dollar, but under massive speculative attack. The dam is about to break.

assets.name: Korean Won
assets.description: South Korea's industrial powerhouse engine. Highly leveraged chaebols make this currency vulnerable.

assets.name: HSBC Holdings
assets.description: The Dragon. Massive exposure to Asia, but a fortress balance sheet. Will it bend or break?

assets.name: Samsung Elec
assets.description: The crown jewel of Korea. Even giants can fall when credit markets freeze.

assets.name: S&P 500 (US)
assets.description: US Markets. Safe haven? Or will the 'Asian Flu' cross the Pacific?

assets.name: Gold
assets.description: The panic button. When currencies fail, gold remains.

events.title: Baht Devaluation
events.description: Thailand unpegs from the dollar. The currency freefalls.

events.title: Contagion Reaches Hong Kong
events.description: Stock markets across Asia plummet. The IMF steps in.

eras.name: The Dot-Com Bubble (1999-2002)
eras.description: Tech stocks are soaring to astronomical valuations. Will you ride the wave or pivot to safety?

assets.name: Amazon.com
assets.description: Books online? Losing money on every sale but making it up in volume. Visionary or delusion?

assets.name: Cisco Systems
assets.description: The plumbing of the Internet. Most valuable company in the world. Priced for infinite growth.

assets.name: Pets.com
assets.description: Sock puppet mascot. IPO fever. No business model. The poster child of the bubble.

assets.name: Qualcomm
assets.description: Mobile revolution leader. Stock up 2,600% in one year. Can trees grow to the sky?

assets.name: eBay Inc.
assets.description: Online auctions. Actually profitable! A rare unicorn in a field of donkeys.

assets.name: Yahoo!
assets.description: The portal to the web. Worth more than Disney and Boeing combined. Ad revenue is king... for now.

assets.name: Microsoft
assets.description: The Evil Empire. Facing antitrust lawsuits, but prints money. A mature tech giant.

assets.name: Intel
assets.description: Inside everything. PC demand is insatiable. The hardware backbone.

assets.name: S&P 500 ETF
assets.description: Diversified exposure. Dragged up by tech, but anchored by the 'Old Economy'.

assets.name: Gold
assets.description: A 'barbarous relic'. Nobody wants gold when Nasdaq returns 80% a year.

assets.name: Coca-Cola
assets.description: Buffett's favorite. Boring, reliable, profitable. Ignored by the dot-com crowd.

assets.name: Johnson & Johnson
assets.description: Band-Aids and baby powder. A defensive fortress when the tech bubble bursts.

assets.name: General Electric
assets.description: Jack Welch's conglomerate. Financial engineering + industrial might. The blue-chip of blue-chips.

events.title: NASDAQ Peaks
events.description: The tech heavy index hits an all-time high of 5,048.

events.title: Pets.com Collapses
events.description: The poster child of the bubble goes under just 9 months after IPO.

eras.name: The Great Recession (2007-2009)
eras.description: The housing market is beginning to show cracks. Subprime mortgages are everywhere.

assets.name: Lehman Brothers
assets.description: 158-year-old bank. Highly leveraged in real estate. 'Too big to fail'... or is it?

assets.name: Bear Stearns
assets.description: The first domino. Heavily exposed to subprime mortgages. Bleeding cash daily.

assets.name: AIG Insurance
assets.description: Insuring the entire global financial system via CDS. If they fail, everyone fails.

assets.name: Citigroup
assets.description: Financial supermarket. Dancing while the music is playing, but the music is about to stop.

assets.name: Bank of America
assets.description: Buying Countrywide Financial? A bold move... or a toxic pill?

assets.name: Goldman Sachs
assets.description: The smartest guys in the room. actively betting against the mortgages they sell you.

assets.name: Apple
assets.description: Just launched the iPhone. Revolutionizing tech, but can it survive a global meltdown?

assets.name: Amazon
assets.description: AWS is growing. E-commerce is sticky. A rare growth story in a dying economy.

assets.name: S&P 500 ETF
assets.description: The broader market. Housing crashes usually drag everything down with them.

assets.name: Treasury Bonds
assets.description: Flight to safety. When banks collapse, the world buys US debt.

assets.name: Gold
assets.description: Hard money. Central banks are printing cash to save the system. Gold loves inflation.

events.title: Bear Stearns Collapse
events.description: The investment bank is sold to JPMorgan for $2 a share.

events.title: Lehman Brothers Bankruptcy
events.description: The largest bankruptcy filing in U.S. history sends shockwaves through the global system.

eras.name: The Everything Bubble (2020-2022)
eras.description: Fed printers are brrr-ing. Crypto is mooning. Meme stocks are defying logic. Can you time the top?

assets.name: Bitcoin
assets.description: Digital Gold. Institutional adoption is here. Laser eyes everywhere. To the moon?

assets.name: GameStop
assets.description: Power to the players. The hedge funds are short, and Reddit is angry. Diamond hands.

assets.name: Zoom Video
assets.description: The new way we live. If you work from home, you use Zoom. Valuation > Exxon Mobil?

assets.name: Tesla
assets.description: EV revolution. S&P 500 inclusion. Is it a car company or a tech company?

assets.name: ARK Innovation
assets.description: Disruptive innovation ETF. Betting on the future, regardless of price.

assets.name: S&P 500
assets.description: The reopening trade. Airlines and Cruise lines are dead, but Tech carries the index.

assets.name: US Dollar
assets.description: Inflation is 'transitory'. Cash is trash... until the Fed hikes rates.

events.title: COVID-19 Crash
events.description: Global lockdowns. Markets plummet 33% in weeks. 'The end of the world'.

events.title: Meme Stock Mania
events.description: Retail traders vs Wall Street. GameStop hits $483. 'We like the stock'.

events.title: The Peak
events.description: Bitcoin hits $69k. Inflation hits 40-year highs. The Fed wakes up.
